name: Avoid thrown Exceptions in servlet methods
description:
Even though the signatures for methods in a servlet include throws IOException, ServletException, it's a bad idea to let such exceptions be thrown. 

This rule report all exceptions in methods named "do*" ( doPost; doGet...) are explicitly handled in servlet classes.
output:
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided:
- The number of violation occurrences
- Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
rationale:
When a Servlet throws an exception, the default error response the Servlet container sends back to the user typically includes debugging information. 
This information is of great value to an attacker. For example, a stack trace might show the attacker a malformed SQL query string, the type of database being used, and the version of the application container. This information enables the attacker to target known vulnerabilities in these components.
reference:
http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/600.html 
OWASP Top 10 2017 Category A3 - Sensitive Data Exposure
remediation: Use of try catch block is recommended.
alternativeName: Ensure to manage an exception in servlet method using a try catch block to prevent exposing system vulnerabilities

qualityStandards.name: Uncaught Exception in Servlet
qualityStandards.description: The Servlet does not catch all exceptions, which may reveal sensitive debugging information.

qualityStandards.name: Sensitive Data Exposure
qualityStandards.description: Many web applications and APIs do not properly protect sensitive data, such as financial, healthcare, and PII. Attackers may steal or modify such weakly protected data to conduct credit card fraud, identity theft, or other crimes. Sensitive data may be compromised without extra protection, such as encryption at rest or in transit, and requires special precautions when exchanged with the browser.
